conclusion: To determine the static friction force on block D, analyze forces on each block using Newton's second law.
Block A has forces: applied force F, normal force N_A, static friction from block B.
Block B has forces: applied force F, normal force N_B, static friction from block A, tension T, normal force N_C.
Block C has forces: tension T, normal force N_C from block B, normal force N_D from block D.
Block D has forces: normal force N_D, static friction from block C, normal force N_C.
All blocks move with the same acceleration a, consider the system as one block.
Total mass of the system is 4m (each block has mass m).
Net force on the system is F, using Newton's second law: F = 4ma.
For block D, static friction equals force required to accelerate block D with acceleration a.
Force required to accelerate block D is f_static = ma.
Substitute a into f_static: f_static = m(F / 4m) = F / 4.
The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D is F / 4.
